Literature Review: The transition to turbulence in pipe flow has been a subject of intense scientific inquiry since Osborne Reynolds' pioneering experiments in the late 19th century. This seemingly simple flow configuration has proven to be a rich source of complex phenomena, challenging researchers for over a century. This literature review aims to synthesize the current understanding of the transition to turbulence in pipe flow from three distinct perspectives: stability and susceptibility of laminar flow, phase transition and spatiotemporal dynamics, and dynamical systems analysis.The stability of laminar pipe flow has been a longstanding puzzle in fluid dynamics. While linear stability analysis predicts that laminar pipe flow is stable for all Reynolds numbers, experiments consistently show transition to turbulence at finite Reynolds numbers. This apparent contradiction was partially resolved by the discovery of transient growth mechanisms. Schmid and Henningson (1994) demonstrated that non-normal modes in pipe flow can lead to significant transient amplification of disturbances, even in the absence of asymptotic instability. This finding opened up new avenues for understanding how finite-amplitude perturbations can trigger transition.Building on this concept, Meseguer and Trefethen (2003) performed high-resolution computations of the linear stability operator, providing precise bounds on transient growth in pipe flow. Their work highlighted the importance of non-modal analysis in understanding the susceptibility of laminar flow to perturbations. Further insights into the role of transient growth in pipe flow transition were provided by Pringle and Kerswell (2010), who identified optimal perturbations that maximize energy growth over finite time horizons.The spatiotemporal dynamics of the transition process have been another focal point of research. Wygnanski and Champagne (1973) identified two distinct turbulent structures in transitional pipe flow: puffs and slugs. Puffs are localized turbulent regions that maintain a constant size as they propagate downstream, while slugs are expanding turbulent regions. The dynamics of these structures have been extensively studied to understand the nature of the transition process.A significant breakthrough came with the work of Avila et al. (2011), who demonstrated that the transition to turbulence in pipe flow can be understood as a directed percolation phase transition. They showed that the spatiotemporal intermittency observed in transitional pipe flow belongs to the directed percolation universality class, providing a connection between fluid dynamics and statistical physics. This finding has profound implications for understanding the critical behavior near the transition point.The dynamical systems perspective has provided yet another lens through which to view the transition problem. Eckhardt et al. (2007) proposed that the transition to turbulence in pipe flow can be understood in terms of a chaotic saddle in phase space. This approach views turbulence as a transient phenomenon, with lifetimes that increase rapidly with Reynolds number. The work of Hof et al. (2006) provided experimental evidence for this view, showing that turbulent puffs have finite lifetimes even above the critical Reynolds number for transition.Recent advances in numerical simulations have allowed for more detailed investigations of the phase space structure of transitional pipe flow. Budanur and Hof (2017) used extreme value statistics to characterize the chaotic saddle, providing new insights into the mechanisms of relaminarization and the statistical properties of turbulent trajectories.The transition to turbulence in pipe flow has also been studied in the context of complex fluids. Samanta et al. (2013) investigated the effects of polymer additives on the transition process, showing that even minute concentrations of polymers can dramatically alter the transition scenario. This work highlights the potential for flow control and drag reduction through the use of additives.While much progress has been made, several open questions remain. The precise nature of the critical point for the onset of sustained turbulence is still debated, as is the universality of the directed percolation scenario across different flow geometries. Additionally, the connection between the dynamical systems view and the statistical physics approach remains to be fully elucidated.In conclusion, the study of transition to turbulence in pipe flow has evolved from Reynolds' original experiments to a multifaceted field incorporating ideas from linear stability theory, statistical physics, and dynamical systems. This rich interplay of perspectives has led to significant advances in our understanding of this fundamental problem in fluid dynamics, with implications for a wide range of applications from industrial pipe flows to blood flow in arteries.
